SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 9-5

How many of these were bachelor's houses? 10

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Every week

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Week day.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Usually without invitation.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Morning

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take patrick" used, or was some other expression common?) You were assured food would be had, if nothing else.

Would be offered food if nothing else.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Tea

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? No

6. Did you ever have a "po' old cow" at your house, although you didn't own one?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, picnics, drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn around wardoni? No

Did you move another at definite times, once a week, once a month, etc.? No
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTYING, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many hours were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's hours? How often did you usually visit neighbors? Every week.

2. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other day? Twice a day.

3. Did you usually visit when not invited beforehand? Yes.

4. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (This is what the term "make patron" used, or some other expression.)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to watch after the children?

6. Did anyone ever make plans for neighbors' visits together to put up decorations, take quilts, or other such activities? No.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, plant drives, or dances in homes? Occasionally.

8. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

9. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn each week, once a month, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities, including the school Christmas tree, plants, etc. If you have not described these in the school yearbook, give details.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1906-7

What material was it made of? Wood

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, etc., organization, etc.? The Community Hall Board

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings and come to the hall in town for other functions, etc.) We used it for all functions in the village, no closer enough to obtain any function.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8), and 10) did the entire family attend? Sometimes.

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Poker, Bridge, Canasta, Rummy, Cribbage, etc.

Was there card playing for a prize? Yes

What dances were popular? Waltz, Square Dance, Schottische, Fox Trot, French Minuet

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Yes, it was accepted, usually it played for just fun.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

The community lunch is done differently nowadays. Groups share a sit together, run at large gatherings change course with coming of color TV foods.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started? Is it still in existence? If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, how it was kept, who acted as librarians, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

Generally, a member of our Parent-Teacher Club helped the library at its doors. Books were let out by bringing them Sat., 10 a.m. - 12 noon, 2 p.m. Books were returned Mon. - Fri., 9 a.m. - 12 noon, 2 p.m.

Some of the members of the library were formed—the local library offers an ideal thing of its kind. It has proved very satisfactory. As the library is almost three years old, books are on loan for only added to yearly—such latest books.
